case_vignette:
A 11-year-old male with past medical history of medulloblastoma is brought to dermatology clinic for evaluation of multiple "moles" on the face, neck, arms and legs. Patient's mother reports developing similar lesions when she was younger and a history of ovarian fibromas.  Examination reveals multiple thin brown pedunculated papules on the cheeks, neck, and upper chest and back. Focal atrophic ovoid papules are appreciated on the palms bilaterally.  The patient's mother has a history of multiple "moles" and ovarian fibromas.  The patient's father has a history of melanoma.  The patient's mother is a 45-year-old female with a history of ovarian fibromas and multiple "moles".  The patient's father is a 50-year-old male with a history of melanoma.

Patient's father reports developing similar lesions when he was younger and a history of testicular fibromas.  Examination reveals multiple thin brown pedunculated papules on the cheeks, neck, and upper chest and back. Focal atrophic ovoid papules are appreciated on the palms bilaterally.  The patient's father has a history of multiple "moles" and testicular fibromas.  The patient's mother has a history of melanoma.  The patient's father is a 45-year-old male with a history of melanoma.  The patient's mother is a 50-year-old female with a history of melanoma.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple "moles" on my face, neck, arms, and legs.
How long have these "moles" been there?
My father mentioned that he developed similar lesions when he was younger, so they might be something I've had for a while or possibly inherited.
Do the "moles" change in color, size, or shape?
I haven't noticed any changes in color, size, or shape of the "moles."
Do you or any family members have a history of any skin or genetic diseases?
Yes, my father has a history of multiple "moles" and testicular fibromas, and my mother has a history of melanoma.
Have you experienced any other symptoms such as freckling in your armpits or groin, bumps around your nails, or issues with vision?
No, I haven't experienced any of those symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Neurofibromatosis type 1.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple "moles" on my face, neck, arms, and legs.
Have these moles changed in appearance recently or have you noticed any new ones?
I have noticed multiple thin brown moles that seem to be hanging off the skin on my cheeks, neck, upper chest, and back, and also some flat and thin papules on my palms.
How old are you, and do you have a personal or family history of any skin conditions or genetic diseases?
I am 11 years old, and my father has a history of similar moles and testicular fibromas. My mother has a history of melanoma.
Are there any neurological symptoms or learning difficulties that you have experienced?
I have a past medical history of medulloblastoma, which is a type of brain tumor.
Final Diagnosis: Gorlin Syndrome (Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome)
